user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
- test_code: a modified metal_shmem_register_generic code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/88.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If the MISRA C rule is not violated, you can just return an empty string for the test code.
Here are the constraints for the test code:
- DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
- The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
- The test code MUST include line breaks.
- The test code MUST preserve the original logic of metal_shmem_register_generic as much as possible.
- You MUST NOT define the main function.
- You MUST NOT define macros.
- The test code MUST not contain any mock functions.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_shmem_register_generic:
```c
int metal_shmem_register_generic(struct metal_generic_shmem *shmem)
{
	/* Make sure that we can be found. */
	metal_assert(shmem->name && strlen(shmem->name) != 0);

	/* Statically registered shmem regions cannot have a destructor. */
	metal_assert(!shmem->io.ops.close);

	metal_list_add_tail(&_metal.common.generic_shmem_list,
			    &shmem->node);
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_shmem_register_generic:
#define metal_assert(cond) metal_sys_assert(cond)
...
extern struct metal_state _metal
...
struct metal_generic_shmem {
	const char		*name;
	struct metal_io_region	io;
	struct metal_list	node;
}
</additional code>
Judge whether the above metal_shmem_register_generic code violates the rule 1.2 or not.
scenario: No violation: the function uses only standard C constructs (function call, pointer dereference, string length check, list manipulation). There are no compiler-specific extensions (no __attribute__, asm, typeof, statement-expression, nested functions, zero-length arrays, or other documented compiler extensions) visible in the provided code. Note: if the macro metal_assert or any of the list/io helpers were implemented using a compiler extension, that would be a violation, but no such implementation details were provided here.
